canonical_explanation.text: The periodic classification of elements is the systematic arrangement of elements based on their properties. Early attempts include Dobereiner's triads (groups of three elements where the middle element's atomic mass is the average of the other two) and Newlands' Law of Octaves (every eighth element has similar properties, like musical notes). Mendeleev arranged elements by increasing atomic mass and predicted properties of undiscovered elements. The modern periodic table, based on Moseley's work, arranges elements by increasing atomic number (Modern Periodic Law). It has 18 groups (vertical columns) and 7 periods (horizontal rows). Elements in the same group have similar properties due to the same number of valence electrons. Across a period, atomic size decreases and non-metallic character increases. Down a group, atomic size increases and metallic character increases.
rules: Dobereiner's triads: atomic mass of middle element = average of first and third.
Newlands' Law of Octaves: every 8th element has properties similar to the 1st (worked up to calcium).
Mendeleev's Periodic Law: properties of elements are a periodic function of their atomic masses.
Modern Periodic Law: properties of elements are a periodic function of their atomic numbers.
Group number = number of valence electrons (for main group elements).
Period number = number of electron shells.
Atomic size decreases across a period (left to right).
Atomic size increases down a group (top to bottom).
Metallic character decreases across a period; non-metallic character increases.

questions.question_text: Dobereiner's triads arranged elements in groups of:
questions.explanation_correct: Dobereiner's triads arranged elements in groups of three. In each triad, the atomic mass of the middle element was approximately the arithmetic mean of the atomic masses of the other two. For example: Li (7), Na (23), K (39) — average of 7 and 39 is 23.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Triads, as the name suggests, always contain three elements (not two A, four C, or eight D). Dobereiner identified several such groups of three elements with similar properties where the middle element's mass was the average of the other two.

questions.question_text: In Dobereiner's triad of Li, Na, and K, the atomic mass of sodium (23) is the ___ of lithium (7) and potassium (39).
questions.explanation_correct: In Dobereiner's triad, the atomic mass of the middle element is the arithmetic mean (average) of the first and third elements. For Li, Na, K: (7 + 39) / 2 = 46 / 2 = 23, which is the atomic mass of sodium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The sum (A) would be 46, the difference (B) would be 32, and the product (D) would be 273 — none of which equals 23. The arithmetic mean (average) of 7 and 39 is exactly 23, matching sodium's atomic mass.

questions.question_text: A major limitation of Dobereiner's triads was that:

options.text: All known elements could be arranged into triads
Only a few elements could be grouped into triads
The triads did not show any pattern
The triads only applied to gases

questions.explanation_correct: The major limitation of Dobereiner's triads was that only a few elements could be successfully grouped into triads. He could identify only three triads from all the known elements. Many elements did not fit into any triad, making it an incomplete classification system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Not all elements could be arranged into triads (A is wrong). The triads that were identified did show a clear pattern of arithmetic means (C is wrong). Triads applied to various elements, not just gases (D is wrong). The limited applicability was the main drawback.

questions.question_text: Newlands' Law of Octaves states that every ___ element has properties similar to the first.
questions.explanation_correct: Newlands' Law of Octaves states that when elements are arranged by increasing atomic mass, every eighth element has properties similar to the first, much like the eighth note in a musical octave. For example, lithium (1st) and sodium (8th) have similar properties.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The law specifically refers to every eighth element (not third A, fifth B, or tenth D). The comparison with musical octaves (where the eighth note resembles the first) is why it was called the 'Law of Octaves'.

questions.question_text: Newlands' Law of Octaves was applicable only up to which element?
questions.explanation_correct: Newlands' Law of Octaves was applicable only up to calcium. After calcium, every eighth element did not have properties similar to the first. This was a major limitation because it worked only for lighter elements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The law did not work beyond calcium (not up to oxygen A, iron C, or zinc D). After calcium, the periodicity of eight broke down. Also, Newlands assumed that only 56 elements existed and that no more would be discovered.

questions.question_text: Which of the following was a limitation of Newlands' Law of Octaves?

options.text: It was based on atomic number
He placed two elements in the same slot and also put unlike elements together

questions.explanation_correct: Newlands placed two elements in the same slot (e.g., cobalt and nickel) and placed dissimilar elements in the same column to force-fit the pattern. He also assumed no new elements would be discovered, and the law worked only up to calcium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Newlands used atomic mass, not atomic number (A). He did not predict new elements (C) — that was Mendeleev's achievement. The law did not work for all elements (D) — only up to calcium. The forced grouping of unlike elements was a major flaw.

questions.question_text: Mendeleev's Periodic Law states that the properties of elements are a periodic function of their:
questions.explanation_correct: Mendeleev's Periodic Law states that the properties of elements are a periodic function of their atomic masses. He arranged the 63 known elements in order of increasing atomic masses and grouped elements with similar properties in the same column.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Atomic number (A) is the basis of the modern periodic law, not Mendeleev's. Number of electrons (C) was not known in Mendeleev's time. Number of neutrons (D) is unrelated to periodicity. Mendeleev specifically used atomic mass as his organizing principle.

questions.question_text: Mendeleev predicted the existence of an undiscovered element he called 'Eka-aluminium'. This element was later discovered as:
questions.explanation_correct: Mendeleev's 'Eka-aluminium' was later discovered as gallium (Ga) by Lecoq de Boisbaudran in 1875. The properties of gallium closely matched Mendeleev's predictions, providing strong evidence for the validity of his periodic table.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Germanium (A) was Eka-silicon. Scandium (C) was Eka-boron. Silicon (D) was already known. 'Eka-aluminium' was specifically the predicted element below aluminium, which turned out to be gallium.

questions.question_text: Which of the following was an achievement of Mendeleev's periodic table?

options.text: It was based on atomic number
It predicted properties of undiscovered elements
It included noble gases from the beginning

questions.explanation_correct: The greatest achievement of Mendeleev's periodic table was that it predicted the existence and properties of undiscovered elements. He left gaps in his table and predicted the properties of Eka-boron (scandium), Eka-aluminium (gallium), and Eka-silicon (germanium).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mendeleev used atomic mass, not atomic number (A). His table did have limitations (C). Noble gases were not known when Mendeleev made his table — they were accommodated later (D). The predictive power was his greatest achievement.

questions.question_text: Which of the following was a limitation of Mendeleev's periodic table?

options.text: It could not predict new elements
It could not accommodate noble gases
The position of isotopes could not be explained
It was not based on any scientific principle

questions.explanation_correct: Mendeleev's table, based on atomic masses, could not explain the position of isotopes. Isotopes of the same element have different atomic masses, so they should technically be placed in different positions. This limitation was resolved when the modern table used atomic number instead.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mendeleev did predict new elements successfully (A). Noble gases were accommodated in a separate group when discovered (B). His table was scientifically based on atomic masses (D). The isotope problem was a genuine limitation of using atomic mass as the basis.

questions.question_text: Mendeleev placed certain elements not in the order of increasing atomic masses. An example of such an 'anomalous pair' is:
questions.explanation_correct: Cobalt (58.9) and nickel (58.7) are an anomalous pair. Despite cobalt having a higher atomic mass than nickel, Mendeleev placed cobalt before nickel to ensure they were in groups matching their properties. Tellurium-iodine was another such pair.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Li and Na (A), C and N (C), and O and F (D) follow the expected order of increasing atomic masses. Cobalt and nickel, along with tellurium and iodine, were the notable anomalous pairs where Mendeleev had to deviate from strict mass order.

questions.question_text: Mendeleev's 'Eka-silicon' was later identified as:
questions.explanation_correct: Mendeleev's 'Eka-silicon' was later identified as germanium (Ge), discovered by Winkler in 1886. The properties of germanium (atomic mass, density, formula of oxide and chloride) closely matched Mendeleev's predictions, further validating his periodic table.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gallium (A) was Eka-aluminium. Scandium (B) was Eka-boron. Titanium (D) was already known. The prefix 'Eka-' meant 'one' in Sanskrit, referring to the element one place below the named element.

questions.question_text: The Modern Periodic Law states that properties of elements are a periodic function of their:
questions.explanation_correct: The Modern Periodic Law, proposed by Henry Moseley, states that the properties of elements are a periodic function of their atomic numbers (not atomic masses). The atomic number is the number of protons in the nucleus, which also equals the number of electrons in a neutral atom.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Atomic mass (A) was Mendeleev's basis, not the modern law. Mass number (C) includes neutrons and differs for isotopes. Number of neutrons (D) varies between isotopes. The modern law uses atomic number, which resolved the anomalies of Mendeleev's table.

questions.question_text: How many groups are there in the modern periodic table?
questions.explanation_correct: The modern periodic table has 18 groups (vertical columns). Groups are numbered 1 to 18. Elements in the same group have the same number of valence electrons and similar chemical properties. Mendeleev's original table had only 8 groups.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 7 (A) is the number of periods, not groups. 8 (B) was the number of groups in Mendeleev's table. 14 (C) is not the number of groups. The modern periodic table has 18 vertical columns called groups.

questions.question_text: How many periods are there in the modern periodic table?
questions.explanation_correct: The modern periodic table has 7 periods (horizontal rows). The period number corresponds to the number of electron shells in the atoms of that period. Period 1 has 2 elements, Period 2 has 8, Period 3 has 8, and so on.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 5 (A) and 6 (B) are incorrect — there are 7 periods. 18 (D) is the number of groups. The 7 periods represent the 7 energy levels (shells) that electrons can occupy.

questions.question_text: An element has electronic configuration 2, 8, 1. It belongs to which period and group?
questions.explanation_correct: An element with electronic configuration 2, 8, 1 has 3 electron shells, so it is in Period 3. It has 1 valence electron, so it is in Group 1. This element is sodium (Na, atomic number 11).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Period 2, Group 1 (A) would have configuration 2, 1 (lithium). Period 1, Group 3 (C) is not possible since Period 1 only has Groups 1 and 18. Period 3, Group 11 (D) is incorrect. With 3 shells and 1 valence electron, the answer is Period 3, Group 1.

questions.question_text: Elements in the same group have the same number of:
questions.explanation_correct: Elements in the same group have the same number of valence electrons (electrons in the outermost shell). This is why they have similar chemical properties. For example, all Group 1 elements (Li, Na, K, etc.) have 1 valence electron.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electron shells (A) determine the period, not the group. Total electrons (C) differ for each element. Protons (D) also differ (they determine atomic number). The common feature of group members is the same number of valence electrons.

questions.question_text: The period number of an element corresponds to the number of:
questions.explanation_correct: The period number of an element corresponds to the number of electron shells (energy levels) in its atom. For example, hydrogen and helium (Period 1) have 1 shell, lithium to neon (Period 2) have 2 shells, and sodium to argon (Period 3) have 3 shells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Valence electrons (A) determine the group number. Protons (C) determine the atomic number. Neutrons (D) have no direct relation to period. The number of occupied electron shells directly gives the period number.

questions.question_text: Across a period (left to right), the atomic size:
questions.explanation_correct: Across a period from left to right, the atomic size decreases. This is because the number of protons (positive charge) in the nucleus increases while electrons are added to the same shell. The increased nuclear charge pulls the electrons closer, reducing the atomic radius.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Atomic size does not increase (A) or remain the same (C) across a period. It does not first increase then decrease (D). The consistent decrease is due to increasing nuclear charge at the same energy level.

questions.question_text: Down a group (top to bottom), the atomic size:
questions.explanation_correct: Down a group, the atomic size increases because a new electron shell is added with each period. Even though the nuclear charge also increases, the addition of a new shell far outweighs the pull of the nucleus, resulting in a larger atomic radius.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Atomic size does not decrease (A) or remain the same (C) down a group. It does not first decrease then increase (D). Each successive element in a group has one more electron shell, consistently increasing the atomic size.

questions.question_text: Which of the following has the smallest atomic radius?
questions.explanation_correct: Chlorine (Cl, atomic number 17) has the smallest atomic radius among the given elements. All these elements are in Period 3, and atomic radius decreases across a period from left to right. Chlorine is furthest to the right, so it has the smallest atomic radius.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Na (A), Mg (B), and Al (C) all have larger atomic radii than Cl because they are further to the left in Period 3. The order of atomic size is: Na > Mg > Al > Si > P > S > Cl. Chlorine, being closest to the right side, has the smallest radius.

questions.question_text: Metallic character across a period (left to right):
questions.explanation_correct: Metallic character decreases across a period from left to right. This is because the tendency to lose electrons (metallic behaviour) decreases as nuclear charge increases. Elements on the left of a period are metals, the middle are metalloids, and the right are non-metals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Metallic character does not increase (A) or stay constant (C) across a period. It steadily decreases from left to right as atoms become smaller and hold onto their electrons more tightly, making it harder to lose electrons.

questions.question_text: Down a group, the metallic character of elements:
questions.explanation_correct: Metallic character increases down a group because the outermost electrons are farther from the nucleus (more shells) and are easier to lose. For example, in Group 1: Li < Na < K < Rb < Cs in terms of metallic character and reactivity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Metallic character does not decrease (A) or stay the same (C) down a group. It can be predicted (D). As atomic size increases down a group, the outermost electrons are held less tightly, making it easier for the atom to lose them — hence greater metallic character.

questions.question_text: The valency of an element with atomic number 15 is:
questions.explanation_correct: An element with atomic number 15 has electronic configuration 2, 8, 5 (phosphorus). It has 5 valence electrons. Since it needs only 3 more electrons to complete its octet (8 - 5 = 3), its valency is 3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The valency is not 5 (A) — while there are 5 valence electrons, the valency is the combining capacity, which is either the number of valence electrons or 8 minus that number, whichever is smaller. 5 > 4, so valency = 8 - 5 = 3. Options C (2) and D (1) are incorrect for 5 valence electrons.

questions.question_text: An element X has atomic number 12. Where is it placed in the modern periodic table?
questions.explanation_correct: Element X (atomic number 12, which is magnesium) has electronic configuration 2, 8, 2. It has 3 electron shells (Period 3) and 2 valence electrons (Group 2). Therefore, it is placed in Period 3, Group 2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Period 2 (A, C) would have only 2 shells. Group 12 (A, D) would be a transition metal group. With configuration 2, 8, 2, the element clearly has 3 shells (Period 3) and 2 valence electrons (Group 2).

questions.question_text: The valency across Period 3 (Na to Cl) follows the pattern:
questions.explanation_correct: Across Period 3 (Na to Cl), the valency first increases from 1 to 4 and then decreases from 4 to 1: Na(1), Mg(2), Al(3), Si(4), P(3), S(2), Cl(1). For elements with more than 4 valence electrons, valency = 8 minus the number of valence electrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The valency is not simply equal to the number of valence electrons for all elements (A). It does not decrease steadily (C). It is not constant (D). The pattern of increase to 4 then decrease reflects how atoms either lose or gain electrons to achieve a stable octet.

questions.question_text: Why did Mendeleev's table need to be revised?

options.text: Atomic mass was found to be the wrong basis; atomic number is the fundamental property

questions.explanation_correct: Mendeleev's table needed revision because atomic mass was not the most fundamental property of elements. Henry Moseley showed that atomic number (number of protons) is the fundamental property that determines an element's characteristics. This resolved anomalous pairs and the isotope problem.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While new elements were discovered (B), that alone did not require revision. The table size (C) was not the issue. Mendeleev did not make calculation errors (D). The fundamental problem was using atomic mass instead of atomic number as the organizing principle.

questions.question_text: Which of the following elements has the largest atomic size?
questions.explanation_correct: Potassium (K, atomic number 19) has the largest atomic size among the given elements. All these elements are in Group 1, and atomic size increases down a group. K has 4 electron shells (2,8,8,1) while Na has 3 and Li has 2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: H (D) has only 1 shell and is the smallest. Li (A) has 2 shells. Na (B) has 3 shells. K has 4 shells and is the largest. Going down Group 1: H < Li < Na < K in atomic size.

questions.question_text: Noble gases are placed in which group of the modern periodic table?
questions.explanation_correct: Noble gases (He, Ne, Ar, Kr, Xe, Rn) are placed in Group 18 of the modern periodic table. They have completely filled outermost shells (except He with 2 electrons, the rest have 8), making them very stable and unreactive.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Group 1 (A) contains alkali metals. Group 17 (B) contains halogens. Group 14 (C) contains the carbon family. Noble gases, with their stable electronic configurations, are placed in the last column — Group 18.

questions.question_text: Mendeleev's 'Eka-boron' was later identified as:
questions.explanation_correct: Mendeleev's 'Eka-boron' was later identified as scandium (Sc), discovered by Nilson in 1879. The properties of scandium matched Mendeleev's predictions for the element that would sit below boron in the periodic table.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gallium (A) was Eka-aluminium. Germanium (B) was Eka-silicon. Titanium (D) was already known in Mendeleev's time. 'Eka-boron' specifically referred to the undiscovered element below boron, which turned out to be scandium.

questions.question_text: An element has the electronic configuration 2, 8, 7. This element is most likely a:
questions.explanation_correct: An element with configuration 2, 8, 7 has 7 valence electrons and is in Group 17 (halogens). This is chlorine (atomic number 17). Elements on the right side of the periodic table (Group 15-17) are non-metals because they tend to gain electrons rather than lose them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Metals (A) are on the left side with few valence electrons. Metalloids (B) are at the border. Noble gases (D) have 8 valence electrons (or 2 for He). With 7 valence electrons, this element is a halogen — a highly reactive non-metal.

questions.question_text: Hydrogen does not have a fixed position in the periodic table because:

options.text: It shows properties of both alkali metals and halogens

questions.explanation_correct: Hydrogen does not have a fixed position because it shows properties of both alkali metals (Group 1) and halogens (Group 17). Like alkali metals, it has 1 valence electron and forms H+ ions. Like halogens, it is a non-metal and forms H- ions (hydrides). This dual nature makes its placement ambiguous.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Being the lightest (A) does not affect placement. Being a gas (C) is irrelevant — many elements in groups are gases. Hydrogen does have 1 electron (D is wrong). Its dual chemical behaviour is the reason for the ambiguity.

questions.question_text: Electronegativity across a period (left to right):
questions.explanation_correct: Electronegativity increases across a period from left to right. As atomic size decreases and nuclear charge increases, atoms have a greater tendency to attract shared electrons. Fluorine is the most electronegative element in the periodic table.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electronegativity does not decrease (A) or stay constant (C) across a period. It does not first increase then decrease (D). The trend is a consistent increase from left to right as atoms become smaller and more eager to attract electrons.

questions.question_text: Newlands compared his Law of Octaves to:
questions.explanation_correct: Newlands compared his arrangement to musical octaves, where the eighth note is a repetition of the first. Similarly, he found that every eighth element (when arranged by atomic mass) had properties similar to the first element. This comparison gave the law its name.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The comparison was not to mathematical equations (A), atomic models (C), or chemical reactions (D). The musical analogy of octaves (where do-re-mi-fa-sol-la-si-do repeats) perfectly described the repeating pattern Newlands observed.

questions.question_text: The modern periodic table resolved the anomalous pairs problem in Mendeleev's table because:

options.text: Atomic number always increases, unlike atomic mass

questions.explanation_correct: The modern periodic table resolved the anomalous pairs problem because when elements are arranged by atomic number (instead of atomic mass), the order always increases without any exception. For example, cobalt (27) correctly comes before nickel (28) by atomic number, even though cobalt has a slightly higher atomic mass.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Simply using a different arrangement (A) without atomic number would not solve the problem. The elements were not removed (C) or combined (D). The key insight was that atomic number, unlike atomic mass, always increases sequentially without anomalies.

questions.question_text: Dobereiner was able to classify all known elements into triads.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Dobereiner could only identify a very limited number of triads (about three). He was unable to classify all known elements into triads, which was a major limitation of his approach.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dobereiner's triads had very limited success. Only a few groups of elements showed the arithmetic mean relationship. The vast majority of elements could not be grouped this way, making it an incomplete classification system.

questions.question_text: Mendeleev left gaps in his periodic table for undiscovered elements.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Mendeleev left gaps in his periodic table for elements that had not yet been discovered. He even predicted the properties of these missing elements, naming them with the prefix 'Eka-'. When these elements were discovered later, their properties matched his predictions remarkably well.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mendeleev indeed left gaps and made bold predictions. This was one of the greatest strengths of his periodic table and helped establish its validity when elements like gallium, scandium, and germanium were discovered.

questions.question_text: In the modern periodic table, elements are arranged in order of increasing atomic mass.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. In the modern periodic table, elements are arranged in order of increasing atomic number (number of protons), not atomic mass. This was proposed by Henry Moseley. While atomic mass and atomic number generally increase together, there are exceptions (anomalous pairs).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The modern periodic table uses atomic number, not atomic mass. This distinction is important because it resolves problems like the anomalous pairs and isotopes that plagued Mendeleev's mass-based arrangement.

questions.question_text: Atomic size increases across a period from left to right.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Atomic size decreases (not increases) across a period from left to right. This happens because while electrons are added to the same shell, the nuclear charge (number of protons) increases, pulling the electrons closer to the nucleus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Across a period, atomic size decreases because the increasing nuclear charge exerts a stronger pull on the electrons in the same shell, drawing them closer. For example, Na > Mg > Al > Si > P > S > Cl in atomic size.

questions.question_text: Non-metallic character increases across a period from left to right.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Non-metallic character increases across a period from left to right. As the atomic size decreases and nuclear charge increases, atoms have a greater tendency to gain electrons (non-metallic behaviour) rather than lose them. The elements become progressively more non-metallic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Non-metallic character does increase across a period. Elements on the left are metals (they lose electrons), those in the middle may be metalloids, and those on the right are non-metals (they gain electrons). The tendency to gain electrons increases from left to right.

questions.question_text: Noble gases were present in Mendeleev's original periodic table.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Noble gases were not known when Mendeleev created his periodic table in 1869. They were discovered later (starting with argon in 1894). When discovered, they could be accommodated in a new group (Group 0/18) without disturbing the existing arrangement — another achievement of Mendeleev's table.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Noble gases were discovered after Mendeleev's table was created. Their successful accommodation in the table without disturbing the existing arrangement was considered a strength of Mendeleev's periodic classification.

questions.question_text: Newlands' Law of Octaves states that every ___ element has properties similar to the first.
questions.explanation_correct: Newlands' Law of Octaves states that every eighth element has properties similar to the first, when elements are arranged in order of increasing atomic mass. This was compared to the octave in music where the eighth note resembles the first.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'eighth'. Newlands observed that the properties of elements repeated every eight elements, similar to the musical scale where the eighth note is a higher octave of the first.

questions.question_text: The modern periodic table has 18 groups and ___ periods.
questions.explanation_correct: The modern periodic table has 18 groups (vertical columns) and 7 periods (horizontal rows). The periods correspond to the number of electron shells, with elements in Period 7 having the most electron shells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is '7'. The 7 periods represent the maximum number of principal energy levels (electron shells) that elements can have. Period 1 is the shortest with 2 elements, and Periods 6 and 7 are the longest with 32 elements each.

questions.question_text: The modern periodic law states that properties of elements are a periodic function of their ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The modern periodic law states that the properties of elements are a periodic function of their atomic number (the number of protons in the nucleus). This was proposed by Henry Moseley and replaced Mendeleev's law based on atomic mass.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'atomic number'. Unlike atomic mass, atomic number uniquely identifies each element and always increases sequentially, resolving the anomalies in Mendeleev's classification.

questions.question_text: Down a group in the periodic table, the atomic size ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Down a group, the atomic size increases because each successive element has one more electron shell than the previous element. The addition of a new shell increases the distance between the outermost electrons and the nucleus, resulting in a larger atomic radius.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'increases'. Each step down a group adds a new electron shell, making the atom larger despite the increasing nuclear charge.

questions.question_text: Across a period from left to right, metallic character ___ while non-metallic character increases.
questions.explanation_correct: Across a period from left to right, metallic character decreases. This is because the increasing nuclear charge makes it harder for atoms to lose electrons (metallic behaviour). Instead, atoms tend to gain electrons, showing non-metallic character.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'decreases'. As you move left to right across a period, elements transition from metals to metalloids to non-metals, showing decreasing metallic character and increasing non-metallic character.

questions.question_text: An element X has electronic configuration 2, 8, 8, 2. What is its atomic number and position in the periodic table?
questions.explanation_correct: The total electrons = 2 + 8 + 8 + 2 = 20, so atomic number is 20 (calcium). It has 4 shells, so it is in Period 4. It has 2 valence electrons, so it is in Group 2. Therefore: atomic number 20, Period 4, Group 2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Atomic number is the total number of electrons (for neutral atom): 2+8+8+2 = 20 (not 18). The number of shells (4) gives Period 4. The valence electrons (2) give Group 2. Option B correctly identifies all three.

questions.question_text: Among Na, Mg, and K, which is the most reactive and why?

options.text: Na, because it has 1 valence electron
Mg, because it has 2 valence electrons
K, because it has the largest atomic size and can lose its electron most easily

questions.explanation_correct: Potassium (K) is the most reactive because it has the largest atomic size among the three. K is below Na in Group 1, so its outermost electron is farther from the nucleus and held less tightly. This makes it easiest for K to lose its electron, resulting in highest reactivity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While Na has 1 valence electron (A), K also has 1 valence electron but a larger atomic size, making K more reactive. Mg (B) is less reactive because it has 2 valence electrons and a smaller size. They are not equally reactive (D). Down a group, reactivity of metals increases.

questions.question_text: How did Mendeleev accommodate noble gases in his table?

options.text: He removed some elements to make space
He created a new separate group (Group 0) without disturbing existing elements
He could not accommodate them at all

questions.explanation_correct: When noble gases were discovered, they were accommodated in a new separate group called Group 0 (now Group 18) without disturbing the positions of existing elements. Since noble gases have zero valency (completely filled outermost shells), a new group with no valency was a natural addition.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Noble gases were not placed in Group 1 (A). No elements were removed (B). They were successfully accommodated (D is wrong). The creation of a new group that naturally fit the table structure was a testament to the strength of Mendeleev's classification.

questions.question_text: Two elements A and B have atomic numbers 11 and 17 respectively. Which of the following is correct?

options.text: A is a metal and B is a non-metal; they form an ionic compound
A is a non-metal and B is a metal

questions.explanation_correct: Element A (atomic number 11) is sodium (Na) — a metal in Group 1 with electronic configuration 2, 8, 1. Element B (atomic number 17) is chlorine (Cl) — a non-metal in Group 17 with configuration 2, 8, 7. Sodium (metal) transfers its 1 electron to chlorine (non-metal), forming the ionic compound NaCl.
questions.explanation_incorrect: They are not both metals (A) or both non-metals (C). A is a metal and B is a non-metal, not the reverse (D). With Na having 1 valence electron and Cl needing 1 electron, they naturally form the ionic compound sodium chloride (NaCl).
